title: After Hack, SEC Names Its First Chief Risk Officer
summary: Gabriel Benincasa is expected to help identify and mitigate risks following 2016 breach of filings database. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday said Gabriel Benincasa would become the regulator's first chief risk officer.

title: Burger-Flipper Arbitrators
summary: The legislation would effectively abolish at-will employment in chain restaurants.. Now that the Fight for $15 movement has achieved a higher minimum wage in New York City, its backers at the Service Employees International Union want to make fast-food workers hard to fire. City Councilman Brad Lander introduced legislation in February that would effectively abolish at-will employment in chain restaurants-those with 30 or more locations nationwide, whether corporate-owned or franchised.

title: The Phony Retirement Crisis
summary: Contrary to the alarms, household savings are growing. But government plans are underfunded.. Lawmakers are taking action to deal with the "retirement crisis." More than 200 House Democrats are sponsoring a bill to expand Social Security benefits, funded by a dramatic increase in taxes. California, Connecticut, Illinois and Oregon have established state-run retirement plans for private sector-workers, which some progressives hope will supplant 401(k)s.

title: Gap, Old Navy to Split Into Two Public Companies
summary: Apparel maker will separate fast-growing Old Navy from struggling Gap brand that once ruled America's malls. Old Navy has outgrown Gap Inc.

title: Taking Back Some Other Guy's Control
summary: Political insurgencies have yet to show a willingness to take responsibility for any tough decisions.. The problem with socialist governments, Margaret Thatcher famously inveighed in 1976, is that "they always run out of other people's money." The problem now confronting many of the world's political insurgencies is surprisingly similar. Only this time it isn't precisely the other guy's money they're after. It's the other guy's control.

title: Japan Grows Nervous About the U.S.
summary: It fears China's advance, America's retreat and South Korea and Taiwan becoming compromised.. The U.S. and China have begun a protracted struggle that could shape global geopolitics for decades. That makes the U.S.-Japan treaty alliance more important than ever for anchoring Asia's stability. President Trump should recognize that any development that undermines the American presence on the Korean Peninsula will also undermine Japan, and with it the whole region.

title: 388 Days in Senate Limbo
summary: That was the wait for a unanimous 'yes' vote. It's time to change the rules.. Something remarkable happened to John Ryder on Thursday. He got a vote in the Senate.

title: Michael Cohen Makes History
summary: There's no precedent for such an attack on the essential nature of an American president.. Michael Cohen is, famously, a lowlife and screwball who's made his living as an enforcer, liar and thug. He is going to prison essentially for these things. He has taken to implying his turning on Donald Trump is linked to an inner moral conversion, which may be true but is conveniently timed: He has nothing to lose and some form of leniency to gain.

title: Poland, Judaism and Historical Memory
summary: It's a complicated story, and politicians too often attempt to simplify it.. Call it the pangs of intimacy. As Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cultivates relationships with Central European heads of state, he has had some uncomfortable moments. A recent spat shows how quarrels over Judaism's history in the region can complicate cooperation.

title: Declare Victory, Not Emergency
summary: Congress gave Trump $1.4 billion for his wall. He wouldn't take yes for an answer.. President Trump's declaration of a national emergency is a perfect example of his tendency to pitch himself into unnecessary conflicts, drawing attention away from his successes.

title: 'A Grand Success!' Review: Feats of Clay
summary: From drawing cartoons at the kitchen table to creating Wallace & Gromit and Shaun the Sheep, a $50-million merchandising bonanza.. Stop motion, a form of animation as old as cinematography itself, is the art of incrementally manipulating puppets-or cut-out pictures, or people-and photographing them in individual frames, which are then projected in rapid succession, making the subjects appear to move and take on a life of their own. It is a time- and money-consuming technique that requires enormous patience and painstaking discipline. Or, as one non-animator once observed with admiration and pity: "Half of your life on your knees, moving a little hand ever so slightly."

title: Measles Cases in Brooklyn's Orthodox Jewish Communities Rise
summary: Outbreak is worst in New York City since 1991. The measles outbreak in Brooklyn's Orthodox Jewish community continues to grow, New York City health officials said Thursday, even after the city ordered schools to bar unvaccinated students in some ZIP Codes from attending.

title: Andre Previn: Remembering a Versatile Musician
summary: A child prodigy whose family fled Nazi Germany achieved fame with Hollywood musicals, European orchestras and in the world of jazz. André Previn, among the 20th century's most redoubtable musicians and certainly one of its most versatile, missed two enviable milestones in dying today. In April, he would have turned 90, and in October the Los Angeles Philharmonic was scheduled to present a new work it had commissioned from him, intended as a highlight of its centennial celebrations. No less important, that premiere would have served as something of a public apology for the Philharmonic's unceremonious treatment of Mr. Previn in the late 1980s, when he was the orchestra's ninth music director.

title: City Council Passes Bills to Protect Private Sanitation Workers
summary: Mayor Bill de Blasio must still sign the passed bills for them to become law. The New York City Council on Thursday passed bills aimed at providing stronger protections for private trash-carting workers against long hours, unsafe conditions and possible union corruption.

title: Unlocking Gap's Valuation Gap
summary: Gap's split from Old Navy leaves questions unanswered about the slower-growing company but at least unlocks a lot of value. In volatile times, sometimes the best path forward is to take separate paths entirely.

title: China Data Weigh on Emerging-Market Currencies
summary: Dollar rises against emerging-market currencies after data showed a slowdown in China's factory activity. Emerging-market currencies fell against the dollar Thursday, after data showed a slowdown in China's manufacturing sector deepened in February.

title: PG&E Says Its Equipment Was Probable 'Ignition Point' of Camp Fire, Takes $10.5 Billion Charge
summary: The utility, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, said it might not be able to continue as a going concern. PG&E Corp. said Thursday it is probable its equipment sparked the deadliest wildfire in California history as it recorded $11.5 billion in charges related to fires over the past two years.

title: Fidelity Posts Record Revenue, Profit in 2018
summary: Firm's operating income rose 19% to $6.3 billion in 2018, and revenue increased 12% to $20.4 billion. Fidelity Investments posted record operating profits and revenue for a third-straight year even as a stock-market selloff late last year shrunk the value of the assets it manages for clients.

title: CVS Names Chief Information Officer to Lead Aetna Integration
summary: Roshan Navagamuwa joined CVS in 2012 and over the past year served as interim CIO. CVS Health Corp. has tapped a new chief information officer tasked with integrating its information technology and data with IT systems used by Aetna Inc., which the drugstore chain acquired last year in a $70 billion deal.

title: House Committees Plans to Interview Trump Organization CFO, Others
summary: Michael Cohen testified that Trump finance chief Allen Weisselberg played role in hush-money payments. WASHINGTON-House Democrats said they would seek testimony from the chief financial officer and other employees of the Trump Organization, potentially including members of President Trump's family, to follow up on accusations of wrongdoing Michael Cohenmade under oath before the House Oversight Committee Wednesday.

title: New York City Ballet Picks New Director in Wake of Scandal
summary: Stafford named artistic director with Whelan as associate artistic director. The New York City Ballet has new leadership, following a lawsuit that rocked the company last year with charges that it fails to provide a safe and fit environment for female dancers.

title: Senate Republicans Urge Trump to Retreat on Emergency Declaration
summary: Republicans close to providing enough votes to pass resolution disapproving of declaration that would shift funds to pay for southern-border wall. WASHINGTON-Senate Republicans are warning President Trump against moving forward with his national-emergency declaration to build a southern border wall and pressuring him to restrict the project's funding to less controversial sources.

title: Israeli Attorney General Lays Out Planned Charges Against Netanyahu
summary: Mandelblit plans to allege bribery, fraud and breach of trust; pink champagne and cigars. Israeli Attorney General Avichai Mandelblitintends to charge Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with bribery, fraud and breach of trust after two years of corruption probes targeting the premier. The charges are pending a pretrial hearing that is likely to take place after the April election.

title: Thirteen Years of Bryce Harper Feels Like Forever
summary: A baseball star signs a deal for the ages. And the eons.. Thirteen years!

title: New York Requests Documents from Facebook, Apps on Data Sharing
summary: Apps shared an array of the user's personal, medical information. A New York regulator is ramping up a promised investigation of how Facebook Inc. gathered sensitive personal information from popular smartphone applications, after a report by The Wall Street Journal revealed that some apps were sending the social-media giant data, including users' body weight and menstrual cycles.

title: Amazon's Project Zero Aims to Help Brands Target Scammers
summary: Retail giant gives companies access to new tool for removing suspected counterfeit listings. Amazon.com Inc. is starting to let brand owners delete listings on its site for products they deem fake, marking a sharp shift in its struggle to fight counterfeiters that cedes some of its responsibility to other companies.

title: Canadian Drug Firm Targeting U.S. City, County Employees Gets FDA Warning Shot
summary: CanaRx specializes in providing low-cost drugs to U.S. customers. WASHINGTON-The Food and Drug Administration sent a warning letter to CanaRx, a Canadian company that makes low-cost prescription drugs available to employees of as many as 500 U.S. towns, cities and school districts.

title: Some States Are Sending Money Back to Taxpayers
summary: Ten years after the recession, many states have revenue surpluses and plan to boost spending or cut taxes.

title: Kushner Pushes Peace Plan on Middle East Tour
summary: President Trump's son-in-law met with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for first time since journalist Jamal Khashoggi's killing. President Trump's senior adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner on Thursday wrapped up a Middle East tour to raise support for an Israeli-Palestinian peace plan, a swing that included his first meeting with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman since the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

title: Oregon Governor Signs First Statewide Rent-Control Measure
summary: Landlords and developers, who argue rent control doesn't create more affordable housing, opposed the move. Oregon enacted the nation's first statewide rent control measure on Thursday, handing a victory to advocates who say low-income people are squeezed by the housing crunch in many major U.S. cities.

title: Party City CFO to Leave for Edgewell Personal Care
summary: The announcement comes at the company reports weaker-than-expected 2018 financial results. Party City Holdco Inc.'s chief financial officer is leaving the company later this month, the specialty retailer said Thursday as it reported weaker-than-expected 2018 financial results.

title: GOP Motions in House Put Pressure on Democrats' Unity
summary: Republicans use procedural voting tactic to push Democrats facing tough re-election to split with leadership. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) is split with her leadership team over how to handle moderate Democrats who are siding with Republicans on procedural votes to carve out independence from their party.

title: Activewear Retailer Bandier Collects $34.4 Million from Eurazeo, C Ventures
summary: Bandier is Eurazeo Brands' third investment following Nest Fragrances and Pat McGrath Labs.. French buyout firm Eurazeo is injecting $25 million in Bandier Corp. to fuel the activewear retailer's growth.

title: Barclays Activist Puts Cap on Potential Stock Gains, Losses With Loan
summary: The activist firm is financing around half of its multibillion-dollar stake in the British bank with a loan from Bank of America. LONDON- Sherborne Investors , the activist firm pushing Barclays PLC to shrink its investment bank, is financing around half of its multibillion-dollar stake in the British bank with a loan from Bank of America Corp.

title: U.S. Homeownership Rate Hits Highest Level Since 2014
summary: Fourth-quarter data suggests shift from renting to owning, especially among 35- to 44-year-olds. The U.S. homeownership rate climbed in the fourth quarter to the highest level in nearly five years, providing fresh evidence that momentum is shifting back to owning instead of renting.

title: Trump Walks on Kim
summary: Give him credit for refusing to accept less than denuclearization.. President Trump's critics are carping that his top-down negotiating model undermined his nuclear summit with Kim Jong Un because the details hadn't been settled on at lower levels of diplomacy. We give Mr. Trump more credit for walking away from a deal that would not have required North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons.

title: Posting 'Revenge Porn' Will Soon Lead to Jail Time in New York
summary: Gov. Cuomo expected to sign unanimously passed bill to make New York the 42nd state to outlaw nonconsensual sharing of intimate images. Gov. Andrew Cuomo is expected to sign a bill approved by lawmakers Thursday outlawing so-called revenge porn and allowing victims to seek a court order requiring websites to remove any illicit images.

title: ShopKo Dividends Paid Out Before Bankruptcy Are Under Investigation
summary: Equity owners led by Sun Capital face questions about $170 million in payouts by retailer as recently as 2015. More than $170 million in dividends that bankrupt retailer ShopKo paid to private-equity firm Sun Capital Partners Inc. and other owners since 2005 are being investigated by a special committee in the chapter 11 proceedings.

title: Europe's Rallying Stocks Leave Investors Skeptical
summary: Stoxx Europe 600 has almost kept up with the S&P 500 this year, but hedge funds and retail investors are steering clear. European stocks are enjoying their best start to a year since 2015, sparking concerns that threats such as slowing growth and a disruptive Brexit could bring the rally to a skidding halt.

title: What Does Kim Want?
summary: The Trump sales pitch depends on persuading the ultimate crime boss to go legitimate.. This column continues to doubt that President Trump can persuade North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un to dismantle his nuclear weapons program, but remains eager to be proven wrong. After the tyrant of Pyongyang signalled last summer that he saw some virtues in a more open, thriving economy, this week's failure to reach an agreement with Mr. Trump suggests Mr. Kim may be content to run a heavily-armed but impoverished country.

title: Bryce Harper, Phillies Reach 13-Year, $330 Million Deal
summary: The pact will keep the slugger in Philadelphia through 2031 and includes full no-trade protection and no opt-out clauses. From the moment Manny Machado signed his giant $300 million deal with the San Diego Padres last week, one question loomed over the baseball world: What did it mean for Bryce Harper, the other-and perhaps even more coveted-26-year-old superstar in search of a new home?

title: HP's Ink Stain Won't Clean Quickly
summary: New problems in printing supplies spark largest one-day selloff in eight years. HP Inc.'s latest results turned out to be a painful reminder that the storied high-tech giant is actually the world's most well capitalized ink company.

title: Uber Is Close to Buying Dubai Ride-Sharing Company
summary: Careem, which says it has more than 30 million users, is expected to be sold for $3 billion. Uber Technologies Inc. is close to buying Careem, the Dubai-based ride-hailing business, for about $3 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Treasury to Sell $87 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department's auctions next week comprise issues of 13- and 26-week bills. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $87 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: Thousands Evacuated in Northern California Flooding
summary: California Gov. Gavin Newsom declares states of emergency in five counties. SAN FRANCISCO-Catastrophic flooding in Northern California left thousands of people evacuated, hundreds of homes underwater and the town of Guerneville in Sonoma County a veritable island.

title: U.S. Economy Grew 2.6% in the Fourth Quarter
summary: For the year, consumer spending was robust thanks to strong job market, tax cuts and household income gains. WASHINGTON-The U.S. economy completed one of the best years of a nearly decadelong expansion, growing at a modest pace in the fourth quarter despite slowdowns elsewhere in the world, turbulent financial markets, trade disputes with China and a partial government shutdown late in the year.

title: Some Uber, Lyft Drivers to Get Stock in IPOs
summary: Ride-sharing companies will give some drivers cash with an option to use it to buy IPO shares. Ride-hailing companies Uber Technologies Inc. and Lyft Inc. are planning to give some drivers money to buy stock in their initial public offerings, a rare move that would grant them access to two of the most hotly anticipated IPOs ever.

title: When Planning for Retirement, Don't Forget Inflation
summary: Retirement columnist Glenn Ruffenach also answers questions about budgets and Social Security benefits. Your recent column about calculating how much money a person needs to save for retirement didn't seem to address inflation. What is a good way to plan for inflation over our retirement years?

title: How A.I. Is Making Supermarkets Less Exhausting
summary: Wallet-free shopping, souped-up grocery carts and robot helpers are making supermarket excursions smarter, easier-and much, much faster. IT'S BEEN YEARS since technology began helping urbanites avoid the teeming aisles and whimsical "organization" of grocery stores. Despite the advent of FreshDirect and Instacart, however, I still make dreaded milk-and-juice runs now and then. The good news: A.I. is turning in-store experiences into equally seamless transactions-no lines or registers, no "chip malfunction," no wait.

title: U.S. Oil Prices Rise Toward Three-Month High
summary: Investors shrugged off U.S.-North Korea impasse and refocused on a bullish weekly report showing a decline in U.S. crude-oil inventories. •U.S. benchmark oil prices rose toward fresh three-month highs Thursday as investors continued to focus on a report showing a large and unexpected drop in U.S. inventories of crude oil.

title: 'By the Way, Meet Vera Stark' Review: Lynn Nottage's Sharp Teeth
summary: A revived play splendidly dramatizes a little known episode of black Hollywood history. New York

title: Tax Refunds Bounce Back After Slow Start
summary: Trump administration has faced criticism over smaller average refunds in wake of new tax law. Average tax refunds rebounded after a weak start to the tax-filing season, according to Internal Revenue Service data released Thursday that was highlighted by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.

title: U.S. Government-Bond Prices Fall on Strong Economic Data
summary: Break in run of lackluster indicators assuages some fears about a possible downturn. U.S. government-bond prices pulled back on Thursday after new data showed the U.S. economy grew at a solid pace at the end of last year, easing concerns that the lengthy economic expansion is headed toward a significant slowdown.

title: States With the Highest/Lowest Mortgage Rates
summary: The state you live in plays a surprisingly significant role in the mortgage rate you end up with. The mortgage rate someone lands when they buy a house depends on many things, including their credit score, debt load and the particular lender. But a new study by online mortgage marketplace LendingTree reveals there's another factor that plays a surprisingly significant role in the rate they lock in: which state they live in. An even bigger surprise? The state that emerged as the bargain of the bunch.

title: 'Apollo 11' Review: Houston, We've Got a Classic
summary: A documentary, best seen in IMAX, forgoes hype and conjures the lunar adventure with spectacular, previously unseen footage.. At liftoff from Kennedy Space Center, we are told by the splendid documentary "Apollo 11," Neil Armstrong's heart rate was elevated only mildly, at 110 beats per minute. It also stood at 110 during the lander's descent to the lunar surface, though it rose to 156 at the moment of touchdown; good to know that the first member of our species to walk on the moon permitted himself some excitement. Your own pulse will pound at many points during Todd Douglas Miller's film, which opens this week exclusively in IMAX, as befits the subject, then widens, or more properly narrows, next week to conventional screens as well. Much of the footage hasn't been seen before, having languished for decades in the National Archives. And it was scanned at high resolution from pristine 65mm source material, so this evocation of the mission half a century ago is as good as it's likely to get-meaning not just good but magnificent.

title: 'Woman at War' Review: Meltingly Appealing Icelandic Weirdness
summary: The tone switches delightfully often in this tale of a fervent battler against an aluminum smelting plant. By now it's well known that power grids are vulnerable to hacking. What's new in "Woman at War," a marvelously loopy and deeply serious film from Iceland, is the spectacle of transmission towers in that nation's highlands being shorted out by a middle-aged woman with a steely eye, a bow and arrow, a backpack full of steel cable, and a consuming determination to banish an aluminum-smelting plant from a vast wilderness. And that's only the first couple of minutes of an eco-comedy concerned with nothing more, or less, than saving the world-where to start, how to go about it, what scale to work on, and what to do if the world declines to be saved on your own fervent terms.

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended Feb. 23
summary: With data from NPD BookScan. NPD BookScan gathers point-of-sale book data from more than 16,000 locations across the U.S., representing about 85% of the nation's book sales. Print-book data providers include all major booksellers, web retailers and food stores. E-book data providers include all major e-book retailers. Free e-books and those selling for less than 99 cents are excluded from the ebook lists. The fiction and nonfiction combined lists include aggregated sales for all book formats (except audio books, bundles, boxed sets and foreign language editions) and feature a combination of adult, young adult and juvenile titles. The hardcover fiction and nonfiction lists also encompass a mix of adult, young adult and juvenile titles while the business list features only adult hardcover titles. Refer questions to Teresa.Vozzo@wsj.com.

title: 'Greta': Big Names, Small Chills
summary: Director Neil Jordan and star Isabelle Huppert fail to spark a poorly written tale of stalking, friendship gone wrong, a dog and a creepy Brooklyn apartment. "Greta" is petit Guignol trying to pass for Grand, a horror flick made by people who forgot to have fun. One of them, the director, Neil Jordan, made a memorable film called "The Crying Game" almost three decades ago. This is the groaning game, an inept tale of danger, entrapment and dismemberment. (It's only a pinkie that gets lopped off, but still.)

title: 'Leaving Neverland' Review: The Dark Side of the Moonwalks
summary: An HBO documentary on Michael Jackson is an appalling story of predatory child sexual abuse, told in such painful detail that it's impossible to dismiss. "Leaving Neverland," which has prompted the Michael Jackson estate to file a $100 million lawsuit against HBO, is an appalling story of predatory child sexual abuse, told in such painful detail and at such heroic length (four hours over Sunday and Monday nights) that it's impossible to dismiss. But what the series also makes clear, beyond almost everything else, is the power of willful blindness.

title: 'Better Things' Review: It's Still as Good
summary: As the show enters its third season-this time without Louis C.K.-Pamela Adlon's heroine remains one of the most original and daring female characters in TV comedy. The comedian Louis C.K. has committed a few outrages, and one would certainly involve the wrench he threw into the works of "Better Things." The acclaimed FX comedy series, created by the comedian and his longtime collaborator, Pamela Adlon, was closing out its second season in late 2017 and had already been renewed for a third when Mr. C.K.'s sexual indiscretions hit the fan. FX fired him, understandably enough. But the sandbagged Ms. Adlon might easily have become the collateral damage of a #metoo moment. And wouldn't that have been ironic?

title: Another Look at State Taxes Versus Services
summary: It can be nice to live in a high-tax state, as long as you can afford to.. The letters of Feb. 25 ("Good Services, State Tax Rates Don't Align") include one from Leon Gottlieb, a reader who touts his relocation from a low-tax state (Tennessee) to a high-tax state (Illinois).

title: Patriots Owner Robert Kraft Pleads Not Guilty to Soliciting Prostitution
summary: Kraft was one of 25 men charged in Jupiter, Fla., as part of a larger investigation that uncovered a network of spas that were allegedly fronts for prostitution. New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft has pleaded not guilty to two misdemeanor counts of soliciting prostitution, according to a filing by his attorney in a Palm Beach County, Fla. court.

title: It's the Value Added, Not the Size, That Makes Colleges Thrive
summary: The current challenges facing small, private higher-educational institutions do not frighten us. We are committed to change, to meeting student needs, and to the power that our smallness brings to us.. Prof. Allen C. Guelzo may be correct on every point about the demographics ("America's Disappearing Private Colleges," op-ed, Feb. 22). No one can be certain how many of the 1,800 private four-year degree-granting institutions will close.

title: GM Says Two Top Executives to Leave the Company
summary: General Motors elevated Gerald Johnson to the post of executive vice president, global manufacturing, where he will also lead labor relations. General Motors Co. announced Thursday the pending departures of two executives who report directly to Chief Executive Mary Barra, the latest in a series of executive shifts at the Detroit car maker.

title: Senator Whitehouse Is Wrong on Amicus Briefs
summary: The Rhode Island Democrat should respect the institutional independence of the Supreme Court and its capacity to regulate the issue, should the need arise.. As a former law clerk to Chief Justice Warren Burger, I couldn't agree more with your editorial "No Friend-of-the-Court Senator" (Feb. 25) about Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse's criticism of the Supreme Court for accepting amicus briefs from organizations without requiring the disclosure of their donors. The Justices are fully capable of assessing the merit or persuasiveness of a brief without knowing how the organization submitting it is funded.

title: Saudi Sisters Stranded in Hong Kong After Holiday Escape
summary: The pair, aged 18 and 20, hide from their family in safe houses, fearing deportation to conservative Middle Eastern kingdom, where renouncing Islam can carry a death sentence. HONG KONG-Two Saudi sisters face deportation from Hong Kong after what they describe as an escape from their ultraconservative and abusive family, among the latest women to flee the Middle Eastern kingdom seeking a freer life abroad.

title: Why Should the EU Have Discriminatory Car Tariffs?
summary: All President Trump is trying to do is to level the playing field. The EU imposes a 10% tax on American cars while our tax on their cars is 2.5%.. Your editorial "Crash on the Autobahn" (Feb. 23) chastises the Trump administration for threatening to impose a hefty tariff on auto imports from the European Union. You counsel continued trade negotiations to solve the disparity in import taxes rather than imposing new car tariffs.

title: Copper Edges Lower After Weak Chinese Economic Data
summary: Prices hit highest level since early July in recent days before recent pullback. Copper prices inched lower Thursday, hovering near their highest level in almost eight months after data showed Chinese factory activity fell to the lowest level in three years in February.

title: U.S. Recorded-Music Revenue Rises Amid Streaming Subscription Surge
summary: Domestic retail revenue grew 12% in 2018 to $9.8 billion as subscriptions to services like Spotify topped 50 million. Revenue from music-streaming platforms now accounts for three-quarters of the music industry's top line, as subscriptions to services including Spotify Technology SA, Apple Inc., Amazon.com Inc. and others in the U.S. grew 42% in 2018 to top 50 million for the first time.

title: Pakistan to Release Captured Indian Pilot, Easing Tensions
summary: Prime Minister says pilot captured after his plane was shot down in clash with Pakistani jet fighters will be freed. LAHORE, Pakistan-Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan said his country would soon release an Indian air force pilot captured Wednesday, a gesture that appeared to dial back a confrontation between the nuclear-armed states after two days of back-and-forth military attacks.

title: Senate Confirms Andrew Wheeler as EPA Head
summary: Vote was 52 to 47, largely along partisan lines. WASHINGTON-The Senate voted Thursday to confirm Andrew Wheeler as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, ratifying President Trump's choice of a former advocate for business interests to lead the agency.

title: David Einhorn, Sunny Side Up
summary: The hedge-fund manager says he will make fewer, bigger bets after a disastrous year. Warren Buffett was probably only half joking when he famously contradicted a famous proverb. It is fine, he said, to put all of your eggs in one basket as long as you "watch that basket closely."

title: Holiday Sales Haven't Rescued J.C. Penney, Victoria's Secret
summary: Retail chains plan to close more stores as they confront shifts in consumer spending. The cruel reality of retailing in America is that the annual holiday splurge is no longer enough to boost the fortunes of chains like J.C. Penney and Victoria's Secret that are struggling to draw in shoppers and compete online.

title: Santander Withdraws CEO Job Offer Over Concerns on Compensation
summary: The unusual U-turn highlights the fraught issue of executive compensation in Europe. Andrea Orcel, one of Europe's highest-profile investment bankers, found himself out of a job Tuesday, when Spain's Banco Santander SA said it would be unacceptable to pay him the amount of money it would have cost to make him chief executive.

title: Starboard Details Opposition to Bristol-Myers Deal for Celgene
summary: Activist investor describes proposed takeover as poorly conceived and ill-advised. Activist investor Starboard Value LP detailed its opposition to Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. 's proposed acquisition of Celgene Corp. and said it plans to organize other shareholders to oppose the $74 billion deal.

title: A Fallen Tree, a Silver Lining
summary: A limb falls on the house, triggering a chance to tackle home improvements along with necessary repairs.. It was pitch dark and pouring rain when Leslie Stack and Frank Rizzo drove home from dinner and arrived at their historic Queen Anne Victorian mansion in Richmond, Va. They took in a horrifying sight: A 175-year-old red oak tree had fallen smack onto their house and was sticking out of their top floor.

summary: Cloud-software company fails to close some big deals, hurting its outlook. Hunting elephants is one thing, but bagging them is another. Just ask Box Inc.

summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Why Serious Cyclists Are Paying More for Titanium Bikes
summary: Bespoke titanium bike frames combine all the best qualities of other materials. But convincing one of the world's top designers to custom-build yours can be an art unto itself. THOUGH STEEL, aluminum, wood, bamboo and magnesium alloy have all been used to craft stylish bike frames, carbon fiber is today the go-to for serious cyclists with lots of cash. Glued and reinforced by epoxy resin, it can now be mass-produced and shaped to achieve an optimum balance between weight, comfort, aerodynamic performance and a mystic quality known in cycling jargon as "stiffness" that efficiently transfers power from your legs to the wheels.

title: Beto O'Rourke Says He Has Reached Decision on Possible 2020 Campaign
summary: Former Texas congressman who is mulling a presidential run won't make another Senate bid. Beto O'Rourke says he has made a decision on his 2020 plans, and a person familiar with his decision says he won't be making another run for the Senate.

title: Is a Flood of Bad News Better Than a Drip, Drip, Drip?
summary: Kraft Heinz's kitchen-sink quarter can be cleansing-if the CEO fully cleared the deck of potential negatives. This earnings season provided its share of disappointments.

summary: Strengthening its brand in the U.S. and diversifying into Asia should help online-travel company shake off weakness in EU. Booking.com is ready for takeoff. Unfortunately for the Amsterdam-based online reservation engine, fewer people in the European Union are looking to travel.

summary: Abu Dhabi naval contractor Privinvest Group also named. Mozambique sued Credit Suisse AG in U.K. court Wednesday over the bank's involvement in $2 billion of debt deals tied to a global corruption scandal.

title: With New Laws and Some Help, Iraq Turned Around Anti-Money-Laundering Problems
summary: The Iraqi government was removed last year from an international watchlist. Seven years ago, Iraq's financial system was beset by problems.

title: Senegal's President Re-Elected After Race Tested by Violence
summary: Marky Sall's two main opponents have questioned the credibility of the vote tally. Senegal's President Marky Sall won re-election, capping days of tense vote tallying following an unusually violent campaign in one of Africa's most stable democracies.

title: India's Economy Did Better Under Modi, If You Trust the GDP

title: In Praise of the Ever-Practical Handkerchief
summary: The humble hankie is no longer as popular as it used to be, which is a shame: Few everyday items are as useful for showing affection and concern.. My father was born in 1925, and like many men of his era he was quite formal in dress. I never once saw him in bluejeans or a T-shirt. When he came home from his medical office at the end of a long day, he kept his coat and tie on until he was ready for bed. And he always carried a neatly pressed white handkerchief in his back pocket.

title: Olympia Scarry on Her Alpine Arts Festival and Honoring Richard Scarry's 100th
summary: Helicoptering a 23-foot replica of the Queensboro Bridge to the top of the Alps? No sweat. Swiss artist Olympia Scarry charts how she runs her Gstaad, Switzerland-based arts festival, Elevation 1049, and how this year she's honoring her grandfather Richard Scarry. 12:30 p.m.-I meet the Elevation 1049 team for a pre-opening lunch meeting with Neville Wakefield, the co-founder and co-curator and longtime collaborator and friend. I also greet the LUMA Foundation's managing director, head of communications and our producer of projects. Honestly couldn't wish for a better group to work with. We meet at the Posthotel, one of my favorite and oldest hotels in Gstaad to discuss logistics, advice, ideas and realities for the coming opening weekend: We have 11 artists and over 270 guests confirmed, so the logistics are intense. Over laughs, I also mention that last night I had to send my father on a rescue mission with a shovel to save Neville and the artist Doug Aitken. After a long flight in from Los Angeles, their car got stuck in a snow ditch trying to get a sneak preview of Aitken's heralded sculpture Mirage Gstaad under the moonlight. Everyone got out safely in the end, but definitely a grand arrival!

title: Making Sense of Irrational Numbers
summary: Pi and other numbers like it show that mathematical systems can be more ambiguous than we usually think. Imagine being asked to pick a number from 1 to 10. That is why March 14, coming up soon, is "Pi day"-not a serious festival but a chance for more people than usual to entertain a few fun thoughts about mathematics.

title: Inside The Shed and Its Inaugural Slate of Performers
summary: The dynamic Hudson Yards cultural center in New York aims to commission innovative works by risk-taking artists of all genres, including the talents in this portfolio. A look at who will headline their first year. Long before The Shed had a name, before its mission had been fully articulated or its physical structure defined, it was just a red dot on a map of New York City's Hudson Yards. Circa 2006, the point marked one of the most valuable plots on this once-sleepy swatch of Manhattan's West Side, and the vague but ambitious plan for it, as set forth by the administration of then-mayor Michael Bloomberg, was to build a cultural institution unlike any other in the city. On April 5, after more than a decade of work and planning, The Shed finally opens, and it's as ambitious as ever. The 200,000-square-foot structure-already known for its movable shell, which rolls out to cover the adjacent plaza-is set to offer equally attention-grabbing programming, striving to be a new model for how culture is created and consumed in the 21st century.

title: 'On Freedom' Review: Nudged to Be Free
summary: We can lose our way when offered too many choices. But are we at liberty when social forces can step in to correct all our personal blunders?. The major challenge of legal and political theory is to develop an account of what it means for people to be free. Historical efforts to answer that question typically have emphasized the correlative rights and duties for all individuals: No one thinks that any coherent notion of liberty lets everyone do just what they want, the rest of the world be damned. A world in which everyone can kill everyone else would breed massive individual and collective insecurity, and private contracts are not sufficient to either secure bodily integrity or protect property rights. There are impossible transactional obstacles in asking every person, born or unborn, to independently make arrangements with all others on these critical topics. Even in a free society, these basic rules of the game have to be defined and imposed collectively.
